TEAMS RATED

Last week-end the Intercollegiate
Lacrosse Association held its annual
meeting in New York. Coach Van
Orman was present, representing
the Johns Hopkins University.
At this meeting three new colleges
were admitted to the Association.
These colleges are St. John's, Western Maryland and Princeton. Both
St. John's and Princeton have been
playing lacrosse for many years, but
are just entering competition for
the championship team which can
be picked only from among colleges
belonging to the Association. Western Maryland has only recently
taken up the old Indian game, but
has prospects for a good team this
year and expect to put out a swimming teams before many seasons
pass.
Korn President

Lou Korn, a former player, was
named president of the Association
at this meeting in New York. Also,
the team ratings for the 1928-1929
season were given out. The Navy
and Union College teams were voted
tie for first. Maryland was second
and Yale third. Army, Rutgers,
Syracuse and Swarthmore were all
rated before Hopkins came. Several
teams followed the Jays, who were
given eighth place. St. John's College was not in the running because
they were not yet connected with
the Intercollegiate Association.
There were no new rules passed
at this meeting, however, several
suggestions that the players all be
numbered to aid in their recognition
were discussed favorably. Several of
the involved rules were put under
question and will appear in a revised
and clarified form in the new guide
which will be published by Spalding,
March 1.
Coach Van Orman made the
statement that another suggestion
which, although it did not reach the
floor of the meeting, has met with
wide approval among the coaches.
This idea was that the ball should
be colored, either a lemon-yellow or
crimson in order to make it easier
for the Lacrosse fans to follow its
progress up and down the field. The
Hopkins mentor stated that he intends to try out the use of a colored
ball at Homewood if the visiting
teams do not offer objections to the
experiment.

Swimming practice has been

Glee Club Makes
Debut Tonight
Unmindful of the superstitions
attendant upon opening on such a
night the Johns Hopkins Musical
Club will present the first concert
of the season tonight, Friday the
thirteenth. The concert will be
given at the Church of the Nativity,
Walbrook. The church is located
on Garrison avenue, one block above
Liberty Heights.
The Glee Club, Banjo Club and
Blue Jay Orchestra will take part.
The program of the Glee Club
will include the "University Ode,"
"Calm As The Night" and "To
Arms." Several Hopkins songs will
be sung. Two negro spirituals will
be represented; "Swing Low, Sweet
Chariot" and "Who Did Swallow
Johnah ?"
The Banjo Club and the Blue
Jays will present several popular
numbers. A dance will be held
after the concert. It is anticipated
that the affair will be highly successful as rehearsals have been taking place for some time.
Osmar Steinwald, who has ably
been coaching the Glee Club this
year, has worked hard with the
members during the past few rehearsals in order to insure success
at the opening concert tonight.

This step is, at least, consistent. Non-athletic activities require as
much time and as much effort as athletics. No distinction should be
shown between the two and just as high grades should be required of
the men interested in one as of those who work at the other. As long
as the black list remains in force it should apply equally to all campus
activities.
But should it remain in force? We believe not. The traditional
policy of the University has been to allow the student complete liberty
so long as he remains a member of the University. President Gilman
inaugurated this principle and his successors have diligently followed
it. The student's time is his own; he is allowed to undertake the
courses of his own choosing, with the exception of a very limited number of required subjects. Every opportunity is given him to specialize
in one branch of work if he sees fit. He is allowed to vary his courses
if he seeks a diversity of knowledge. There is only one requirement:
he must keep up a certain standard of work. If he does not, he is
dismissed from college. This provision for expulsion is all that is
needed. The black list finds no logical place in the existing scheme.
Each student is, and should be, compelled to keep up a high standard
of work. If he does keep up that standard, his actions outside the
classroom should not be questioned. If he does not, he should be
summarily dismissed. There should be no half-way position.

parts of the world. The American

of Students is the largest and most

are the International University
Federation for the League of Nations, the International Student
Service, which is closely related in
origin and purpose to the World
Student Christian Organization, and
the Pax Romana. In spite of the
fact that so many of our country
students so unforunately do not
know of the International Confederation of Students as well as the
other organizations of a similar nature, all these bodies are having a

This step is, at least, consistent. Non-athletic activities require as
much time and as much effort as athletics. No distinction should be
shown between the two and just as high grades should be required of
the men interested in one as of those who work at the other. As long
as the black list remains in force it should apply equally to all campus
activities.
But should it remain in force? We believe not. The traditional
policy of the University has been to allow the student complete liberty
so long as he remains a member of the University. President Gilman
inaugurated this principle and his successors have diligently followed
it. The student's time is his own; he is allowed to undertake the
courses of his own choosing, with the exception of a very limited number of required subjects. Every opportunity is given him to specialize
in one branch of work if he sees fit. He is allowed to vary his courses
if he seeks a diversity of knowledge. There is only one requirement:
he must keep up a certain standard of work. If he does not, he is
dismissed from college. This provision for expulsion is all that is
needed. The black list finds no logical place in the existing scheme.
Each student is, and should be, compelled to keep up a high standard
of work. If he does keep up that standard, his actions outside the
classroom should not be questioned. If he does not, he should be
summarily dismissed. There should be no half-way position.
